title: A Pragmatic Note on Evaluating Generative Models with Fréchet Inception Distance for Retinal Image Synthesis
author: Yuli Wu (Institute of Imaging & Computer Vision, RWTH Aachen University), Fucheng Liu (Institute of Imaging & Computer Vision, RWTH Aachen University), Rüveyda Yilmaz (Institute of Imaging & Computer Vision, RWTH Aachen University), Henning Konermann (Institute of Imaging & Computer Vision, RWTH Aachen University), Peter Walter (Department of Ophthalmology, RWTH Aachen University), Johannes Stegmaier (Institute of Imaging & Computer Vision, RWTH Aachen University)
background: The paper evaluates generative models for retinal image synthesis using the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) and discusses its limitations in aligning with downstream task performance.
contribution: This paper introduces a critical examination of FID as a generative model evaluation metric, emphasizing the need for metrics aligned with practical applications in downstream tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional metrics like FID are widely used but often misalign with task-specific performance metrics in the biomedical field.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work highlights inconsistencies between commonly used evaluation metrics and actual application performance, suggesting that downstream task assessment is a superior evaluation approach.

key_innovation: It underscores the disconnect between generative model evaluation metrics and their efficacy in real-world applications, advocating for prioritizing task performance in evaluations.
real_world_impact: This study could influence how researchers evaluate generative models in medical imaging, potentially leading to improved outcomes in training for specific biomedical tasks.
limitations: The paper may not consider all generative evaluation metrics beyond those discussed, potentially overlooking other relevant methodologies.

new_terms.Fr\u00e9chet Inception Distance (FID): **Fréchet Inception Distance (FID)** is a metric that measures the difference between two probability distributions — real and generated images — based on their features extracted from a neural network.
